description: `Erection of a two storey self-contained 2 bedroom dwelling to the side of 48 Angus Close
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: As required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The development hereby permitted shall be carried out in accordance with the materials specified on the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding submitted drawing number 48AC-109, no development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant and materials to be stored within the site curtilage (c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for work traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment.(j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.(l) hours of operation.(m)Visitors routes for construction traffic.(n) Proposed temporary traffic restrictions.(o) Arrangements for turning delivery vehicles(p) To allow continued safe and clear access to the footway serving Nos. 36 to 46 Angus Close,  including for the collection of refuse and recycling bins. Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase. In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including HouseExtensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby approved shall not commence until a Sustainable Drainage Strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan of surface water drainage for the site using Suds methods has been submittedto and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved Sustainable Drainage Strategy prior to the first occupation of the dwelling and maintainedthereafter for the lifetime of the development.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to prevent the increased risk of flooding by ensuring the provision of a satisfactory means of surface water disposal is incorporated into the design and the build of the proposed development, in accordance with Policies 5.2 and 5.3 of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

No development shall commence until a scheme of soft landscaping and replacement trees, which shall include indications of which shall include indications of all existing trees and hedgerows on the land, and details of any to be retained, together with measures for their protection, in the course of the development, shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. Any mature trees that are removed shall be replaced with two replacement trees. The approved scheme shall be implemented so that planting is carried out no later than the first planting season following occupation of the development or the completion of the development whichever is sooner. All planting materials shall be maintained for five years and any trees or plants removed, dying, being damaged or becoming diseased within that period shall be replaced in the next planting season with others of similar size and species to those originally required to be planted unless the Council gives written consent to any variation.Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions)of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of Part 1 of Schedule 2 of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no extensions (including conservatories, porches, dormer windows and loft extensions) to the building hereby approved shall be erected within the site curtilage. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties and safeguard the cohesive appearance of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Develop

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the south east elevation of the development hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy AdoptedApril 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted details of the refuse and recycling facilities shall be submitted and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory refuse and recycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The car parking accommodation shall be provided on site in accordance with drawing number 48AC-102-A 'Proposed Plans' and shall be provided with a hard bound dust free surface, adequately drained before the development to which it relates is occupied and thereafter it shall be kept free from obstruction at all times for use by the occupier of the development and shall not thereafter be used for any purpose other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of the development and visitors to it.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking accommodation and to avoid the congestion of surrounding roads by parked vehicles in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including HouseExtensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority, within 3 months of first occupation of the development a Post-Construction Review Certificate issued by the Building Research Establishment or other equivalent assessorsconfirming that the development has achieved not less than the CO2 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes level 4. Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of evidence required for Post Construction Stage from Ene1 & Wat1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Technical Guide. Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105l/p/ day must be submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The residential unit hereby approved shall not be occupied until the development has been built in accordance with the requirements of Category 2 of the Building Regulations document titled 'Approved Document M - Access to and use ofbuildings'.Reason: In the interest of inclusive design and accessibility in accordance with Policy 3.8 of the London Plan.

By the time the development hereby permitted is substantially complete, visibility sight line splays of 2m; x 2m shall be provided in each direction at the access and shall be permanently retained free from any obstruction to visibility higher than 1.0 metres above the surface of the adjoining highway.Reason: In the interests of vehicular and pedestrian safety in accordance with Policy T1 (Transport Safety) of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Unitary Development Plan First Alteration and Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

---OFFICER REPORT---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2012 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling with a detached garage.ProposalThe application seeks the erection of a detached double garage with habitable accommodation in the roof space, following demolition of the existing garage.Consultation8 properties were notified of the proposal. 2 objections were received. The material issues raised are summarised as follows:- Scale and height- Detailed design- Loss of privacy- Highway safety- The intended use of the buildingOne neutral comment was also received, which raised concerns about the use of the building.Officer Response: These issues will be considered below.Surbiton CAAC - Objection on the grounds of inappropriate external finishes.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact on the character and appearance of the area;- The impact on heritage assets;- The impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers;- Highway safety;- Car parking; and- Trees and landscape.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The area surrounding the site is not characterised by large, detached garages, although there are a few examples, notably immediately adjacent to the site at 12 Sylvan Gardens. This has a fairly straightforward design, with a rectangular footprint, two garage doors and a first floor window in the front elevation, and a gable roof. While its scale is towards the upper bounds of what might be considered reasonable, it nevertheless has the appearance one might expect of a garage on the plot of a large, detached, suburban dwelling. In contrast, the proposed garage would have an unusual design, with a two storey structure topped by a flat roof projecting out from the eastern side elevation. It would also be excessive in scale, rising to a maximum height of 6.6m above ground level (0.6m above the adjacent garage) and having a footprint of approximately 65sqm (30% larger than the adjacent garage). The proposed siting of the building would serve to emphasise its scale, since it would be positioned well forward of the adjacent garage, achieving only a very slight degree of separation from the back edge of the pavement of Sylvan Gardens. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development would appear as an unduly prominent and incongruous feature within the Sylvan Gardens street scene, resulting in material harm to the character and appearance of the area. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy D3 of the London Plan and policy DM10 of the Core Strategy.Heritage AssetsSection 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Paragraphs 193 to 202 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance. The site is located within the Southborough Conservation Area. The significance of the conservation area is as an area of large detached houses dating from the 1860s - 1930s surrounding Southborough House, an 1808 grade II listed building by the architect John Nash. As noted above, officers consider that the proposed development would result in material harm to the character and appearance of the area. It follows that the development would fail to preserve the character and appearance of the area.In addition to the concerns highlighted above, officers consider that the proposed use of uPVC windows would fail to respect the high quality, historic character of the area. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development would result in less than substantial harm to the significance of the conservation area. The public benefits of the proposal will be weighed up in the conclusion of this report.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Given the presence of the existing garage at 12 Sylvan Gardens, officers consider that the proposed development would not appear overbearing or unduly deprive neighbouring occupiers of natural light. The proposed roof lights in the western roof slope may provide some views over 12 Sylvan Gardens but these would largely be obscured by the adjacent garage and could be further limited through the imposition of a condition requiring obscure glazing. Subject to this condition, officers are satisfied that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Highway SafetyPolicy T4 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should reflect and be integrated with current and planned transport access, capacity and connectivity. Where appropriate, mitigation, either through direct provision of public transport, walking and cycling facilities and highways improvements or through financial contributions, will be required to address adverse transport impacts that are identified. Development proposals should not increase road danger.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires development proposals to have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure they are not adversely affected.The existing garage is not served by a vehicular crossover and none is proposed under the current application. While vehicles in the area are likely to be moving at a slow speed and pedestrians are unlikely to frequently use the pavement in front of the garage, manoeuvering vehicles across the pavement into and out of a double garage would pose a danger to both other vehicles and pedestrians alike. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy T4 of the London Plan and policy DM10 of the Core Strategy.Car ParkingPolicy T5 of the London Plan 2021 states that developments should provide cycle parking at least in accordance with the minimum standards set out in Table 10.2 and Figure 10.3, ensuring that a minimum of two short-stay and two long-stay cycle parking spaces are provided.Policy DM8 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require new development to provide facilities on-site for cyclists as appropriate, including showers, lockers and secure, convenient cycle parking, in accordance with the minimum standards set out in the London Plan.The existing dwelling benefits from a driveway large enough to safely accommodate two vehicles, as well as an integrated single garage and the detached single garage that would be demolished as part of the development. The proposal would result in a net increase of one on-site car parking space, bringing the total for the site to five spaces.Policy T6.1 of the London Plan states that a property of the size in question, in an area with a PTAL of 0, should have a maximum of 1.5 car parking spaces. A higher level of provision may be considered but only where this would support additional family housing. As the proposal would not support additional family housing, it is considered to be contrary to policies T6 and T6.1 of the London Plan and policy DM8 of the Core Strategy.Trees and LandscapePolicy G7 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should ensure that, wherever possible, existing trees of value are retained. If planning permission is granted that necessitates the removal of trees, there should be adequate replacement. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 expects new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by TPOs are not adversely affected.The application form states that there are neither any trees or hedges on the application site nor any trees and hedges adjacent to the site that may be important as part of local landscape character. This is clearly false, since the site contains a large number of trees/hedges on the site (notably a leylandii hedge immediately adjacent to the site of the proposed garage) and the character of the area is defined, in large part, by its sylvan character. All of the trees on the site are protected by virtue of being located within a conservation area.The applicant has failed to consider these trees and hedges in any of the application documents. It follows that the applicant has failed to demonstrate that the proposed development would not have an unacceptable impact on trees worthy of retention. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy G7 of the London Plan and policy DM10 of the Core Strategy.Other MattersConcerns have been raised by neighbouring occupiers regarding the intended use of the building. While the building may be of a size and design such that it could potentially be converted to a self-contained dwelling at a later date, this is not what has been applied for and is something that would require further permission should the current application be granted. Accordingly, officers have assessed the application on the basis of what has been submitted.ConclusionThe proposed development, by reason of the scale, form, height and siting of the proposed garage, would appear as an unduly prominent and incongruous feature within the Sylvan Gardens street scene, resulting in material harm to the character and appearance of the area. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012. Officers attach significant weight to this harm.The proposed development would also result in an excessive concentration of car parking spaces on the site, which could not be accessed in a safe manner. The proposal is therefore contrary to the aims of promoting sustainable transport and ensuring the safety of highway users, and is contrary to policies T4, T6 and T6.1 of the London Plan 2021 and policies DM8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012. Officers attach significant weight to these harms.The applicant has failed to demonstrate that the proposed development would not result in harm to trees worthy of retention. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy G7 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012. Officers attach significant weight to this harm.Finally, the proposed development would result in less than substantial harm to the significance of the Southborough Conservation Area. This must be weighed against the public benefits of the scheme.The public benefits of the scheme are effectively nil. The applicant suggests that it would alleviate parking issues on surrounding streets but officers do not accept this, since the site is already well served by car parking spaces and the proposal would not provide for vehicular access to the proposed garage. Officers therefore consider that there are no public benefits to the scheme that might outweigh the harm to the significance of the conservation area. It follows that the proposal is contrary to policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM12 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012. Officers attach significant weight to this harm.The only other benefits associated with the proposal are those very limited, private benefits associated with improving the quantity and quality of the accommodation at the site. Officers attach limited weight to this.The impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable. This is a neutral matter.Having regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be granted, officers conclude that planning permission should be refused.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal---END OF OFFICER REPORT---

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.12 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no objections have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers note that the current application is a revision of previously refused application ref: 20/02708/HOU. The principle issue with the refused application was the extension of the existing rear dormer. The proposal of this refused application would have resulted in an incongruous that would be visually intrusive and detract from the character and appearance of the host property and the surrounding area. The proposed rear dormer does not extend the existing rear dormer within the current application thereby addressing this issue.The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Due to the scale and siting of the proposed development, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a detached dwelling. The application site is located in Southborough Conservation Area5 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. Surbiton Neighbourhood CAAC - no objectionThe key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Impact to the Southborough Conservation Area.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: While the proposed single storey rear extension would not strictly conform to the parameters set by the Residential Design SPD, in terms of depth, the proposed development would have a modest height and roof form that is in keeping with the original dwelling. As such, officers consider that the proposed development would appear a subordinate and appropriate addition to the original dwelling and, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the separation distance between the proposed development and neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Paragraphs 193 to 202 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC 1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer Comment: The significance of the Southborough Conservation Area is as an area of large detached houses dating from the 1860s - 1930s surrounding Southborough House, an 1808 Grade II listed building by the architect John Nash. As noted above, officers conclude that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the significance of the Southborough Conservation Area, but rather preserve it. As previously mentioned, the proposed development would be in keeping with host property and as such would maintain the character of the immediate surrounding area. Given no harm to heritage assets has been identified in this case, it is not necessary to weigh up the proposals against any public benefits.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Officer ReportIntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2012 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008Application SiteThe application site is occupied by a two storey semi detached building.ProposalThe application seeks permission for the erection of single-storey rear and side extensions with associated changes to fenestration.Consultation14 properties were notified of the proposal. One representation was received.Concerns were raised in relation to fencing between the application property and No.8 Landseer Road and the proposed building of a structure on the shared boundary, or on the adjoining property. Both matters are civil and are to be addressed privately between the parties.Concerns were also raised with impact on residential amenity - this is covered later in the assessment.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Rear ExtensionThe proposed single storey extension would project 3.5m and 6m from the rear wall of the existing building, with a flat roof design (3m in height) and 2no roof lights, one of which is a lantern style.  The extension would align with No.8 Landseer Road and extend 4.4m across the rear elevation. The remainder of the elevation would be 6m in depth, but would maintain the setback of the existing rear extension that is 3m deep. As such, the extension would project only additional 3m beyond the built form which already exists to the side adjoining No.12 Landseer Road.Side ExtensionThe is a minor extension to the existing side extension of 1 m and the removal and replacement of a ground floor side window. The external materials are satisfactory and would match the existing building. The proposed addition of a window to the side elevation at first floor is satisfactory subject to the use of obscure glazing to be secured by condition.The proposed alterations to the front elevation will involve removal of a garage door to be replaced with a smaller door and window.  There is evidence of similar alterations in the street and on this basis officers consider these alterations to be acceptable. It is noted that existing plans show that the garage has already been altered internally and couldn't be used for the parking of a motor vehicle. The proposed development would retain sufficient space for the storage of bicycles. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The extensions are single storey, to the rear and either align with, or are sufficiently set back from buildings on neighbouring properties. None of the proposed windows or doors present concerns in terms of overlooking, loss of privacy, or daylight and sunlight.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.There is provision for parking on site and the loss of the garage is not considered to have any impact on the provision of parking in the immediate area.   ConclusionHaving regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.Background PapersIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 The Plans / Drawings / Documents submitted with the application are available on the Council's website.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal

We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

Application SiteThe application site is occupied by a two storey detached building.ProposalThe application seeks permission for the erection of single storey front, rear and side elevations. Consultation9 properties were notified of the proposal. 2 representations were received.  The material planning concerns are summarised below:The development does not reflect the character of other houses within the streetInappropriate design/layoutAn existing window on the side elevation that is not shown on the drawings and associated loss of privacyOther concerns were raised regarding the intended use of the extension labelled storage, however the property is a residential dwelling and therefore limited to activities of a residential nature and scale. AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The development includes extensions to all elevations of the building as follows:Front elevation - 2m extension to accommodate a new front porch and roof;Side elevation (North east) - 8m side extension set back 2m from the front elevation, maintains existing set back from the boundary;Rear elevation - 3.4m deep on one side and 2.5m on the other to create a full width extension; Side elevation (South east) - 10m deep, located directly on the boundary, no setback from the front elevation. Garage door to the front elevation, window and door to rear elevation.All extensions would be single storey, comprise a pitched roof design 2.5 in height to the eaves and use materials to match the existing. The siting and design of the proposed window and doors are considered acceptable.Whilst the majority of works raises no officer objection, the side extension (left hand side when viewed from the street) raises concerns in relation to its overall scale and design.In particular, the extension would not be setback from the front elevation (contrary to SPD Policy Guidance 35) and result in a 12m extension the full length of the host building. There is a complete lack of any detail or punctuation to the side elevation of the extension, with little consideration given to the overall relationship of the extension and its relationship between the host building and neighbouring properties. The combination of the excessive depth and poor design of this side extension, result in an unsatisfactory appearance to neighbouring properties. Officers acknowledge the scale of homes in the surrounding area however further consideration is considered necessary to  better reflect the character and appearance of the surrounding area and the proportions of the host building.Having regard to the above, officers do not consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed side extension ( south east elevation) would extend the full length of the host building, directly on the boundary, from the front wall of the host building to the rear wall of the extended part of the building. This would result in a blank wall extension 12.5m in length with no articulation or window detail to soften its appearance to the adjoining properties on Berrylands. In particular Nos.41 and 43  Berrylands that are immediately adjacent to the extension and would look directly at the extension from the rear of their properties. The combination of the extensive depth and solid form of the extension is considered to have an undue impact on the visual amenities of adjoining properties. Whilst officers raise no objection to a side extension in principle, it is not considered the design has taken into account the visual amenity of surrounding properties. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would not be acceptable.ConclusionHaving regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be approved, officers conclude that planning permission should be REFUSED.
